awd_titl_txt: Optimizing Motor Coordination through Principles of Motor Relearning
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans often have to engage in the process of changing and refining existing movement patterns, when engaging in normal behaviors as well as in rehabilitation. The goal of this project is to examine this process of "motor re-learning" in complex motor tasks. This project is significant because it will advance theoretical understanding of the principles that drive motor re-learning, and illuminate how these principles can be used to develop new methods of training in healthy individuals. The project includes study of re-learning in violinists, generating outreach and broadening participation in STEM research, and building knowledge of motor learning in musical performance. The project will involve an educational component that provides training to graduate and undergraduate students in conducting research. The knowledge to be gained may have important implications for enhancing movement rehabilitation in individuals with physical disabilities, thereby advancing fundamental science supporting the national health and welfare.  
 
Learning one motor skill can exert a powerful influence on subsequent motor learning. These effects can either promote or hinder learning, and can persist for months or years. Motor learning is complex, as even behaviors that seem quite simple can depend on coordination of multiple joints and multiple muscles. This project will alter this dependence, using a human-computer interface. Humans will learn to move a cursor on a screen using gestures.  The experiment will change the function mapping the gestures into cursor movement, across or within training sessions. The expected findings will advance theories of motor learning, which largely ignore the existence and influence of previously learned coordination patterns.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Humans often have to engage in the process of changing and refining existing movement patterns, when engaging in normal behaviors as well as in rehabilitation. The goal of this project was to examine this process of "motor re-learning" in complex motor tasks. Theoretical understanding of the principles that drive motor re-learning can help understand how these principles can be used to develop new methods of training. The project included experimental lab studies using an instrumented glove, and field experiments that involved the study of re-learning in violinists and cellists.

Intellectual merit of the project is based on our development and application of a new quantitative of measure of similarity between pairs of complex motor tasks. This new measure captures the degree of overlap between patterns of multi-joint coordination. Broader impacts of the project encompass public engagement in a community-based "science, technology, engineering, arts and mathematics" (STEAM) research project as well as educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in Kinesiology and Biomedical engineering.

This project yielded three main results. First, in laboratory experiments, we showed that the ability to re-learn patterns of movement coordination correlated with the degree to which a desired pattern was geometrically similar to old familiar patterns. We also found that the ability to reorganize coordination patterns also depended on the amount of practice on the prior task. Because these results fall in line with prior anecdotal evidence of re-learning in real-world tasks (i.e., tasks that may take months or years to learn), these results show the feasibility of using this experimental paradigm to understand re-learning in reasonable time frames amenable to controlled experimental study.

Second, we conducted field experiments in violin and cello players to understand re-learning in real-world contexts. The purpose of the field study was to engage a large number of student and expert musicians in STEAM research focused on motor re-learning.  We used motion capture technology to examine how musicians across a broad range of ages and skills adapt how they play a simple and well-known melody on violins or cellos that were modified such that the spatial arrangement of strings on the instrument was more or less similar to the conventional string arrangement. Over 200 students, teachers, and family members engaged in this outreach activity. Analyses of the motion capture and audio data show that participants were able to modify their well-established movement patterns (acquired over years or even decades), to play the melody on the modified instruments, usually within 30 attempts. Our results suggest that flexibility to reorganize these patterns may depend on both age and expertise level.

Third, the project provided educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students in Kinesiology and Biomedical engineering. Students developed a wide range of skills related to design and analysis of the experimental paradigm, analyzing experimental data, conducting field experiments, and training in the ethics of conducting human subject research. These have resulted in 10 manuscripts related to the project and 2 conference publications. In addition to publication in journals, we also participated in additional outreach activities tailored toward the general public and school-aged students, such as the Michigan State Science Festival and Grandparents University as well as the Milwaukee Maker Faire, where we highlighted the potential of STEM research and careers in addressing these important societal challenges.


Last Modified: 12/07/2023
Modified by: Rajiv Ranganathan
